title: If the actual universe is infinite, could there be a solid mass somewhere that is bigger than our observable universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Universe is not infinite, it is just inconceivably large. Let me explain… Let us postulate that there are an infinite number of stars - this cannot be true, otherwise we, and everything in the Universe, would be inside a continuous star, a blending of these infinite stars. OK, so no ‘infinite Stars’… Now postulate an Infinite Universe - as there are not Infinite Stars, and assume a moderate spread of non-infinite stars throughout it, the space between stars would tend towards infinity… this is the thing with Infinity, it goes on for ever. As we can see trillions of stars and galaxies, we can come to the conclusion that space is NOT infinite, just very large - so large, in fact, that, due to expansion of space from dark matter/energy, most of the Universe is so far away that we will never see it due to causality. As to your question; in an infinite Universe, theoretically anything is possible (with the right conditions/energy states), but, as we have observed, there are limits for certain bodies/Stars, and due to gravitation vs internal radiation pressure there cannot be solid bodies over a certain size/mass. So… No!

The observable (known) universe isn’t infinite. It’s certainly huge, but it’s size can be captured in a number (billions of light years across). After about 46.5 billion light years in any direction, we reach a “horizon” beyond which we can’t observe anything anymore. Objects beyond that point are moving away faster than light can return to us. That’s the end of the known universe. The entire universe (not restricted to what we observe) has a curvature, curving either in on itself our outward or, if neither, perfectly flat. If it’s perfectly flat, it is infinite. As you’d imagine, these are very difficult things to measure. Especially for an object as immense as a universe. Without getting you (and maybe me) lost in complexity, let’s just note that current measurements show the larger universe to be very, very close to flat. Hence (probably) infinite.

No. The actual universe isn’t infinite, but regardless of that, there are limits to the mass of any body, and they preclude any mass in the universe being much bigger than the largest stars. The limits are called the Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff limit for cold bodies like neutron stars, and the Chandrasekhar limit for white dwarf stars. For any masses greater than these limits, gravity will overcome the nuclear forces at work and they would become black holes.
